cover_page.title: Mass Ave. Bike Lane Improvement
cover_page.author: Chris Murphy
cover_page.audience: To the City of Boston and Massachusetts Department of Transportation

intro.p: Boston is a city well known for its traffic congestion and bad drivers. In an effort to beat the congestion and go green, many people have turned to biking as an alternative method of transportation in the city. While Boston has become increasingly bike friendly over the years, there are still many problem areas, the two most prominent being Commonwealth Avenue and Massachusetts Avenue. These two roadways account for largest contributions to bike accident numbers in the city. Although Commonwealth Ave. has a higher total number of accidents, Mass Ave. has the most potential to increase the safety of bike travel through upgrades to the roadway.

p.crnt_cond: From the Huntington Ave. intersection to the Charles River Bridge is the most problematic section of Mass Ave. This stretch of road is characterized by poor road conditions, dark areas, and random sharrows, or shared bike/car lanes.
p.subj_hist: The vast majority of Boston bike infrastructure has been installed very recently, with most improvements taking place within the last decade. Since 2008, over 90 miles of bike lanes and markings have been put in place. An additional 3600 public bike parking spots have also been installed in the same time frame. It is clear that the city is still undergoing the process of becoming bike friendly and the improvements to Mass Ave. would be the next logical step in this process.

p.scope: The city of Boston must give funding to the Massachusetts Department of Transportation (MassDOT) to organize the construction necessary to improve bike safety on the highlighted stretch of Mass Ave. When completed, the improved bike lanes will increase travel safety and efficiency while satisfying the demands of Boston bike advocate groups.
p.objective: The proposed project would include repaving most sections of Mass Ave, followed by creating clear markings for the bike lanes. It would also include reclaiming the areas around the Huntington Ave. and Boylston St. intersections, where mismanaged construction has left concrete barriers indefinitely blocking the bike lanes. Lastly, there would be lighting upgrades along the stretch from Newbury St. to the Charles River Bridge.

approach.p: To implement the changes, the first step that must be taken is having the MassDOT hire out a private construction company to take on the upgrades. From there, a plan must be created to carry out the construction process with minimal disruption to daily traffic flows. Ideally, the ripping, paving, and repainting process could be completed along the 1.2-mile stretch within 2 weeks of night work. Since the installation/upgrade of streetlights on the sidewalks is a more intensive but much less disruptive process, it could take closer to a full month to complete.

feasibility.p: The two main obstacles in the process are costs and disruptions to traffic flow. The latter problem could be best mostly resolved by limiting work to night shifts and if necessary, weekends. Since the department of transportation already has allotted budgets for roadwork and improvements, the funding problem is mostly a matter of securing those funds through petitions and demonstrations as to why the Mass Ave. upgrade is a pertinent problem.

conclu.p: Performing these upgrades will increase both the usability and safety of bike travel along a major city road. Indirect affects of the construction would hopefully be an increase in bike users and decrease in traffic congestion. Overall, the changes will leader to improved transportation in the city of Boston.
